title: Manifest Destiny
subtitle: Westward Expansion (1840s)

sections.title: Oregon Trail
sections.summary: I'm Samuel, sixteen, and our family has been on the Oregon Trail for six months. We left Independence, Missouri in the spring of 1846 with everything we owned packed into a covered wagon. Two thousand miles of prairie, mountains, rivers, and desert separate us from Oregon's Willamette Valley.

sections.title: Whose Land?
sections.summary: But the land isn't empty. We've passed through territories of the Pawnee, Sioux, Shoshone, and dozens of other Native nations. They watch our wagon trains from hills, sometimes trading with us, sometimes just observing.

sections.title: 54-40 or Fight
sections.summary: Oregon itself is disputed territory. Britain and America both claim it through competing treaties and exploration. The boundary hasn't been settled.

sections.title: Reaching Oregon
sections.summary: After six months, we finally reach Oregon's Willamette Valley. The land is beautiful—green, fertile, watered by rain. We claim 640 acres under Oregon's provisional land laws.

sections.title: The Cost of Destiny
sections.summary: Manifest Destiny has given America vast new territory. Oregon, Texas, and soon California and the Southwest will add millions of acres to the nation. Americans are flooding west, building farms, towns, eventually states.

vocabulary.definition: Belief America was destined by God to expand across North America.
2,000-mile route from Missouri to Oregon used by westward migrants.
1845 admission of Texas (former Mexican territory) as state.
Slogan demanding all Oregon to latitude 54°40'.
Compromise border between U.S. and Canada in Pacific Northwest.
